snippet.title: Mouse Trap: The Board Game - PlayStation 4 Gameplay
snippet.description:
Stop what you're fonduing! Mouse Trap is back with a snap!

Join your friends and race to collect the most cheese. Choose your mouse, your outfit, and go! Strategise as you play. Pick-up cheese, steal cheese, and win with the most cheese! When the other players get too bold, trigger the action contraption and watch the famous chain reaction unfold. Will it work? Hold your breath and feel the tension!

It's the classic board game as you've never played it before, with a vibrant 3D board, cheese machine, bonus game featuring Riggs the cat, and real tactical play! Race into this colourful, fun and immersive world today. It's as fun as cheese can brie!

Mouse Trap (C) Hasbro
Developed and published by Marmalade Game Studio
Also available on Nintendo Switch, iOS and Android

#theforeseenarcade #ps4 #playstation4 #mousetrap #hasbros #boardgame #boardgames #board_games #board_game #mouse_trap #marmaladegamestudio

FUN FACT: The original board game first debuted in 1963 by Ideal and Marvin Glass & Associates. Over the years it saw refreshed redesigns, including ones from Milton Bradley and the game's new IP owner Hasbro. As far as video games are concerned, the first game based on it is Mouse Trap Hotel, a GameBoy exclusive platformer by Imagineering and Electro Brain, but it wasn't the straight adaptation of the original board game. In fact, the board game's digital adaptations were usually relegated to compilations. The first was the GBA compilation from 2005 that had Simon and Operation, a 2007 DS compilation that came with Clue, Perfection and Aggravation and finally EA's Hasbro Family Game Night 3 for Wii, Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3. Ah, and there was also a Mouse Trap themed minigame on the long-defuct Hasbro Arcade app for iOS. It wouldn't be until 2023 where the game was finally given a standalone digital adapation of its own, when Marmalade Game Studio (who also did The Game of Life 2016 and its sequel) got Hasbro's blessing to do so. It first came out on Android in March, then on iOS a month later. The Switch version then came around in August, with the PlayStation 4 version finally releasing in October, all within the same year. It is yet to be released on Xbox One, though.

And in case you hadn't noticed, the game's AI opponents are named after famous mice and rats from animated movies and cartoons.
